items.title: Trump begins crackdown on immigration | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>The United States has started conducting deportation flights using Air Force planes. As Customs and Border Protection confirmed to DW, a C-17 cargo plane, carrying 80 Guatemalan migrants, departed on Thursday evening. US President Donald Trump also ordered 1,500 more military personnel to the border with Mexico, like here on the Paso del Norte International Bridge. Since taking office, President Trump has signed a series of executive orders on migration.

Trump also left thousands of Afghans refugees in limbo after the suspension of a resettlement program.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Putin: Russia ready for talks with US | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Russia's leader, Vladimir Putin, has given his first public reaction to comments made by his US counterpart, Donald Trump, following his inauguration earlier this week. Putin praised Trump as a quote 'clever, pragmatic man'.

Meanwhile, there are growing signs that Russia's war economy is under increasing pressure. Media reports suggest Russian President Vladimir Putin is worried about the state of the economy, while some influential business leaders have raised the alarm over bankruptcies.

items.title: Thousands flee fighting in DR Congo as M23 rebels advance | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>The UN says its peacekeepers are engaged in intense fighting against rebel forces in eastern parts of Democratic Republic of Congo. In recent weeks, M23 fighters have captured key towns in one of Sub-Saharan Africa's most mineral-rich regions close to the border with Rwanda. They're now closing in on the city of Goma. The UK, United States and France are all urging citizens to leave the city, home to more than a million people.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Pistorius says Europe must shoulder security burden | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>German Defense Minister Boris Pistorius says Europe needs to take responsibility for its own security. He made the remarks in Lithuania, where he was overseeing preparations for a German army deployment designed to strengthen NATO's eastern border. Pistorius also visited the Polish military airport Jasionka near Rzeszow where he met his Polish counterpart Wladyslaw Kosiniak-Kamysz.

items.title: Storm Eowyn slams UK following trail of destruction in Ireland | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Storm Eowyn has slammed into Scotland and Northern England, after leaving a trail of destruction across Ireland. 

The Republic of Ireland recorded wind gusts of 183 kilometres an hour -- its strongest on record. Eowyn left almost one million households and businesses in Ireland without power. Scotland and the North of England are also taking a battering from the storm, with rail services cancelled and schools closed out of safety concerns. 

Chapters:
0:00 The record breaking storm
0:38 Andreas Wolff, Journalist

items.title: California firefighters continue to battles fresh blazes | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Fire crews in California are still battling fresh wildfires. The Hughes Fire has burned through more than 40 square kilometres of trees and bush north of Los Angeles. Firefighters are working to keep the flames from spreading further. Evacuation orders relating to the blaze, which affected tens of thousands of people, have now been lifted. A fire in Ventura County also prompted evacuations. Two new fires have also been reported in the San Diego area.  

Chapters:
0:00 Firecrews continue their battle
0:31 Tori Renae Norville, UCCE Fire Science Advisor

items.title: Can Friedrich Merz win over female voters? | Berlin Briefing Podcast
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Michaela Küfner, DW Chief Political Editor:
He himself recognises that the CDU for success needs women voters. But the younger the women are that get polled, the worse he does. Below 18, he's even below 9%. Well, you can say that doesn't really matter because they're not going to vote anyway. The voting age in Germany is 18, but above that it's not that terribly much more. And he just simply comes across as a man of the 90s. He's tone deaf to the issue of women's representation. Just as an example, in 2023, there were seven tickets for the Munich Security Conference for his party. He sent seven men. He doesn't have anyone who's very a close advisor to him who's female, his spokespeople, all men. Only the head of the Konrad Adenauer house of the party, that's a female speaker.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

For more news, analysis and background information on the German election 2025 go to our dedicated page: https://www.dw.com/en/german-election-2025/t-70794502

items.title: Who is Friedrich Merz, Germany's likely next leader? | Berlin Briefing Podcast
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>John Kampfner, Journalist and Author:
He's a man who, as you say, he's been in politics for a long time. He's acerbic. He doesn't suffer fools gladly. He's capable of being quite rude to people. He knows his mind. Both because of his relationship to Angela Merkel and feeling that she had stabbed him in the front and the back, and is very keen to do the same now to her during this election campaign and afterwards. He has committed what, for some traditional Germans think is a cardinal sin and worked in the private sector for the asset company Blackrock and sort of a big global company, which in the sort of millennial feeling of Germany's centre-left, is regarded as beyond the pale.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: How Germany's super-rich stay super-rich | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>The number of billionaires is rising rapidly worldwide, including in Germany. Despite an inheritance tax, wealth continues to grow untaxed for the ultra-wealthy. How is that possible? 

Ahead of the elections in Germany, most political parties overall promise tax relief in their election manifestos. While the Greens, SPD and BSW propose reforms to the inheritance tax aimed at generating an additional €3 billion annually, other parties advocate for reductions. The AfD's proposal could even slash annual inheritance tax revenue in Germany by as much as €10 billion. These policies could widen the gap between the rich and the poor. 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

For more news, analysis and background information on the German election 2025 go to our dedicated page: https://www.dw.com/en/german-election-2025/t-70794502

items.title: How Russia is attempting to undermine this eastern European nation | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Moldova's prime minister accuses Russia of causing a humanitarian crisis in the breakaway state of Transnistria. The territory is internationally recognized as part of Moldova, but Russia has long stationed troops in the narrow strip of land that borders Ukraine. In this interview with DW Editor-in-Chief, Manuela Kasper-Claridge, Moldovan PM Dorin Recean explains how Russia is attempting to put a wedge between Transnistria and the Moldovan government, at the cost of the people living there. 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Friedrich Merz: What to expect from Germany’s likely next leader | Berlin Briefing
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Friedrich Merz is the frontrunner to become Germany’s next leader after February’s elections. If he succeeds, he’ll face huge challenges: restoring economic growth after two years of recession, and delivering political stability after the infighting of the outgoing coalition. Experts warn that the stakes for a Merz-led government will be high: failure to deliver could fuel the far right. In this edition of Berlin Briefing, DW’s Richard Walker and Michaela Küfner break it all down with writer John Kampfner. Who is Friedrich Merz? Why did he have a feud with Angela Merkel? How would he deal with Donald Trump, Vladimir Putin, the Ukraine war and the challenge of China? And can he deliver the reboot that he says Germany needs?

Links:

Michaela Küfner on Friedrich Merz vs Olaf Scholz: https://youtu.be/WaBvj_GqbRE?feature=shared

John Kampfner: https://www.jkampfner.net

DW’s Christoph Hasselbach on Friedrich Merz & Donald Trump: https://www.dw.com/en/donald-trump-germany-politics/a-71365721

DW’s Rosalia Romaniec on Merz’s party and Ukraine: https://www.dw.com/en/german-election-2025-ukraine-defense-spending-nato-cdu-csu-v2/a-71277591

RSS feed DW Berlin Briefing: https://rss.dw.com/xml/podcast_Berlin_Briefing
